Fernando Research Group

From Processing to Performance: Understanding Organic Electronic Materials

Instrumentation

The Fernando Research Group has access to state-of-the-art instrumentation for materials characterization and device fabrication. Our facilities enable cutting-edge research in organic electronic materials.

Scanning Probe Microscopy

Conductive Atomic Force Microscopy (c-AFM) for nanoscale electrical characterization enables direct correlation between surface morphology and electrical properties. Our system provides standard AFM modes for topographical and mechanical properties analysis with environmental control capabilities for in-situ measurements. Resolution extends down to sub-nanometer scale for detailed surface morphology analysis, making it ideal for studying organic thin films and device interfaces.

Thin Film Fabrication

Solution processing equipment for organic electronic materials includes spin coating and blade coating systems for uniform film deposition. Our controlled atmosphere glove box enables device fabrication under inert conditions, preventing oxidation and contamination. Thermal annealing systems provide post-processing optimization capabilities, allowing precise control over film crystallinity and morphology.

Optical Characterization

UV-Vis-NIR spectroscopy for absorption and transmission measurements covers the full solar spectrum. Photoluminescence spectroscopy provides emission characterization for understanding electronic excited states. Our solar cell characterization setup includes solar simulator and I-V measurements for complete device performance analysis, with temperature-dependent capabilities for thermal stability studies.

Structural Characterization

Access to synchrotron facilities for GIWAXS measurements provides detailed molecular packing and crystalline structure analysis. Collaborative access to X-ray diffraction facilities enables comprehensive structural characterization. Partnership with regional facilities including Brookhaven National Laboratory and Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory expands our analytical capabilities.

Computing Resources

High-performance computing clusters for materials simulation and modeling enable theoretical studies complementing experimental work. Data analysis software including ImageJ, Gwyddion, and custom Python scripts provide comprehensive analytical capabilities. Collaborative computing resources through Union College IT infrastructure and cloud computing access support large-scale computational studies.
